au.edu.federation.caliko.utils

Class Vec2f

  • java.lang.Object
    • au.edu.federation.caliko.utils.Vec2f

  • public class Vec2f
extends Object
    A two-dimensional vector consisting of x and and y values stored as floats.

    The x and y properties are declared publicly for performance reasons.

    Version:
    0.3 - 15/10/2014
    Author:
    Al Lansley

    • Constructor Detail

      • Vec2f

        public Vec2f()
        Default constructor.

        The x and y properties of the Vec2f are implicitly set to 0.0f by Java as that's the default value for primitives of type float. This allows for fast creation of large numbers of Vec2f objects without the need to have the x and y properties explicitly set to zero.

      • Vec2f

        public Vec2f(Vec2f source)
        Copy-constructor.

        Parameters:
        source - The source Vec2f to copy the x and y values from.

      • Vec2f

        public Vec2f(float x,
             float y)
        Two parameter constructor which allows for creation of a Vec2f from two separate float values.

        Parameters:
        x - The x value of this Vec2f.
        y - The y value of this Vec2f.

    • Method Detail

      • approximatelyEquals

        public boolean approximatelyEquals(Vec2f v,
                                   float tolerance)
        Check if this Vec2f is approximately equal to another Vec2f.

        If a tolerance of less than zero is provided then an IllegalArgumentException is thrown.

        Parameters:
        v - The Vec2f to compare to
        tolerance - The value which both components of each vector must be less than to be considered equal
        Returns:
        A true or false value indicating if the vectors are approximately equal.

      • plus

        public Vec2f plus(Vec2f v)
        Add the provided Vec2f to this Vec2f and return the result in a new Vec2f.

        The plus method does not modify 'this' Vec2f.

        Parameters:
        v - The Vec2f to add.
        Returns:
        A Vec2f which is the result of component-wise addition of this Vec2f and the provided Vec2f.

      • minus

        public Vec2f minus(Vec2f v)
        Subtract the provided Vec2f from this Vec2f and return the result in a new Vec2f.

        The minus method does not modify 'this' Vec2f.

        Parameters:
        v - The Vec2f to subtract.
        Returns:
        A Vec2f which is the result of component-wise subtraction of the provided Vec2f from this Vec2f

      • times

        public Vec2f times(float value)
        Component-wise multiply (i.e. scale) this vector by a float and return the result as a new vector.

        This Vec2f remains unchanged so you cannot call foo.times(2.0f); to double it - you must call foo = foo.times(2.0f);

        Parameters:
        value - The value to scale this Vec2f by.
        Returns:
        A scaled version of this Vec2f.

      • dividedBy

        public Vec2f dividedBy(float value)
        Component-wise divide this vector by a float and return the result as a new vector.

        This Vec2f remains unchanged so you cannot call foo.dividedBy(2.0f); to halve it - you must call foo = foo.dividedBy(2.0f);

        Parameters:
        value - The value to divide this Vec2f by.
        Returns:
        A scaled version of this Vec2f.

      • negated

        public Vec2f negated()
        Negate this vector and return the result as a new Vec2f. The provided vector remains unchanged.
        Returns:
        A negated version of this Vec2f.

      • set

        public void set(Vec2f source)
        Set the x and y values of a given Vec2f object from a source Vec2f.
        Parameters:
        source - The source Vec2f from which to copy the values.

      • set

        public void set(float x,
                float y)
        Set the x and y values of a given Vec2f object from two floats.

        This method isn't necessarily required as the x and y properties are public, but it doesn't hurt either.

        Parameters:
        x - The x value to set.
        y - The y value to set.

        public float length()
        Return the length (i.e. magnitude) of this vector.
        Returns:
        The length of this vector.

      • normalise

        public Vec2f normalise()
        Normalise and return the provided vector.

        If the magnitude of the vector is zero then the original vector is returned.

        Returns:
        A normalised version of this vector.

      • normalised

        public static Vec2f normalised(Vec2f source)
        Return a normalised version of the provided vector. The provided vector argument itself remains unchanged.

        If the magnitude of the vector is zero then the original vector is returned.

        Parameters:
        source - The vector to normalise.
        Returns:
        A normalised version of this vector.

      • getDirectionUV

        public static Vec2f getDirectionUV(Vec2f a,
                                   Vec2f b)
        Calculate and return the direction between two points as a unit vector.

        The direction returned is the direction from a to b. If the opposite direction is required then the result can simply be negated.

        Parameters:
        a - The first location.
        b - The second location.
        Returns:
        FIX THIS
        See Also:
        negated()

      • distanceBetween

        public static float distanceBetween(Vec2f v1,
                                    Vec2f v2)
        Calculate and return the distance between two Vec2f objects.

        The distance is calculated as the square root of the horizontal distance squared plus the vertical distance squared.

        Parameters:
        v1 - The first vector location.
        v2 - The second vector location.
        Returns:
        The distance between the two vector arguments.

      • dot

        Calculate and return the dot product (i.e. scalar product) of this Vec2f and another Vec2f.
        Parameters:
        v1 - The first Vec2f with which to calculate the dot product.
        v2 - The second Vec2f with which to calculate the dot product.
        Returns:
        The dot product (i.e. scalar product) of v1 and v2.

        Parameters:
        v - The Vec2f with which to calculate the dot product.
        Returns:
        The dot product (i.e. scalar product) of this Vec2f and the 'v' Vec2f.

      • getUnsignedAngleBetweenVectorsDegs

        public static float getUnsignedAngleBetweenVectorsDegs(Vec2f v1,
                                                       Vec2f v2)
        Calculate and return the unsigned angle between two Vec2f objects.

        The returned angle will be within the half-open range [0.0f..180.0f)

        Parameters:
        v1 - The first Vec2f
        v2 - The second Vec2f
        Returns:
        float

      • zcross

        public static int zcross(Vec2f u,
                         Vec2f v)
        Method to determine the sign of the angle between two Vec2f objects.

        Parameters:
        u - The first vector.
        v - The second vector.
        Returns:
        An indication of whether the angle is positive (1), negative (-1) or that the vectors are parallel (0).
        See Also:
        https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7785601/detecting-if-angle-is-more-than-180-degrees

      • getSignedAngleDegsTo

        public float getSignedAngleDegsTo(Vec2f otherVector)
        Get the signed angle in degrees between this vector and another vector.

        The signed angle, if not zero (i.e. vectors are parallel), will be either positive or negative: - If positive (between 0.0f and 180.0f), then to rotate this vector to the other vector requires a rotation in an anti-clockwise direction, - If negative (between 0.0f and -180.0f), then to rotate this vector to the other vector requires a rotation in a clockwise direction.

        Internally, once the unsigned angle between the vectors is calculated via the arc-cosine of the dot-product of the vectors, the zcross(Vec2f, Vec2f) method is used to determine if the angle is positive or negative.

        Parameters:
        otherVector - The Vec2f that we are looking to find the angle we must rotate this vector about to reach.
        Returns:
        float

      • getConstrainedUV

        public static Vec2f getConstrainedUV(Vec2f directionUV,
                                     Vec2f baselineUV,
                                     float clockwiseConstraintDegs,
                                     float antiClockwiseConstraintDegs)
        Constrain a direction unit vector to be within the clockwise and anti-clockwise rotational constraints of a baseline unit vector.

        By default, the FABRIK algorithm solves an IK chain without constraints being applied between adjacent bones in the IK chain. However, when simulating real-world objects, such angles between bones would be unrealistic - and we should constrain the bones to (in this case, in 2D) specified clockwise and anti-clockwise rotational limits with regard to adjacent bones in the chain.

        This method takes a direction unit vector and a baseline unit vector, and should the difference between those vectors be greater than the allowable clockwise or anti-clockwise constraint angles, then it clamps the returned direction unit vector so that it cannot exceed the clockwise or anti-clockwise rotational limits.

        Parameters:
        directionUV - The direction unit vector to constrain
        baselineUV - The baseline unit vector with which to constrain the direction
        clockwiseConstraintDegs - The maximum clockwise rotation that may be applied to the direction unit vector
        antiClockwiseConstraintDegs - The maximum anti-clockwise rotation that may be applied to the direction unit vector
        Returns:
        Vec2f

      • rotateRads

        public Vec2f rotateRads(float angleRads)
        Method to rotate this Vec2f by a given angle as specified in radians.

        Positive values rotate this Vec2f in an anti-clockwise direction. Negative values rotate this Vec2f in a clockwise direction.

        The changes are applied to 'this' vector, and 'this' is returned for chaining.

        Parameters:
        angleRads - The angle to rotate this vector specified in radians.
        Returns:
        Vec2f

      • rotateDegs

        public static Vec2f rotateDegs(Vec2f source,
                               float angleDegs)
        Method to rotate this Vec2f by a given angle as specified in degrees.

        This static method does not modify the source Vec2f - it returns a new Vec2f rotated by the specified angle. Positive values rotate the source Vec2f in an anti-clockwise direction. Negative values rotate the source Vec2f in a clockwise direction.

        This method does not convert degrees to radians and call rotateRads() - instead it performs a degrees to radians conversion and then uses identical code from the rotateRads() method to rotate the vector whilst avoiding the additional function call overhead.

        Parameters:
        source - The vector to rotate.
        angleDegs - The angle to rotate the source vector specified in degrees.
        Returns:
        Vec2f

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Return a concise, human-readable description of this Vec2f as a String.

        The x and y values are formatted to three decimal places - if you want the exact values with no formatting applied then you can access and print them manually (they're declared as public).

        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
        Returns:
        String
